message_1: What is the surface area of an activated carbon sample (mass = 2 g) according to the BET theory, if the nitrogen adsorption isotherm data at 77K resulted in a multilayer adsorption uptake of 4.36 mmol/g and the monolayer adsorption uptake is 1.54 mmol/g? (Assume a molecular cross-sectional area of nitrogen as 0.162 nm2)
message_2:
To calculate the surface area of the activated carbon sample according to the BET theory, we can use the following formula:

Surface area (SA) = mass × monolayer adsorption uptake × molecular cross-sectional area of nitrogen × Avogadro's number

First, we need to convert the monolayer adsorption uptake from mmol/g to mol/g:

1.54 mmol/g = 1.54 × 10^(-3) mol/g

Now, we can plug the values into the formula:

SA = 2 g × 1.54 × 10^(-3) mol/g × 0.162 nm² × 6.022 × 10^(23) molecules/mol

SA = 2 × 1.54 × 10^(-3) × 0.162 × 6.022 × 10^(23)

SA = 3.084 × 10^(-3) × 0.162 × 6.022 × 10^(23)

SA = 0.499656 × 6.022 × 10^(23)

SA = 3.006 × 10^(23) nm²

So, the surface area of the activated carbon sample is approximately 3.006 × 10^(23) nm².
